text: [Music]
hey everybody how's it going my name is
Jeremy Burr I'm a Senior Solutions
architect focused on manage service for
Apache Flink and today I'm really
excited to talk about a cool new feature
that was just launched within the manage
service for Apache Flink one of the
pieces of feedback that we get from
customers all the time is just how
difficult it is to get up and started
runting new Apache Flink workloads so so
to counter that we created a new feature
within manage service for Apache Flink
called
blueprints with blueprints you can get
up and started in just a few minutes and
with the click of a button to launch
endtoend streaming pipelines and
streaming
applications and that includes data
generation stream storage stream
processing and in one of the blueprints
we even feature stream delivery to a
destination so let's go over to the AWS
Management console and find out what
blueprints are all about so in the AWS
Management console we're going to
navigate over to our managed Apache
Flink
service and once we're on the msf page
we can then click on create streaming
application and you'll see here you're
presented with two options you can
either create an application from
scratch where you're developing your
applications locally and then deploying
those application jars or application
files onto the manage
service but if you're just trying to get
started just trying to get a feel for
msf or you just want to see the easiest
way to launch your applications you can
select use a
blueprint and when you click that button
you'll see just what this blueprint
launches it is data generation into an
Amazon Kinesis data stream and that data
is then piped into our manage service
for Apache flank that application is
going to do some general aggregation of
the data and then it's going to write
that data to Amazon S3 durably
stored so if we come down we can give
the application a name let's call it my
Flink
application and we can click on deploy
blueprint this will take a few minutes
to launch so we'll pause the video here
and come back when it's
ready okay it has been about 10 minutes
and the application has launched from
the
blueprint now we can see that it is
running and we can see all the details
about how this was launched the
application actually uses two CL
formation templates one to get the
assets for the code and the second one
to launch the infrastructure needed for
the
application if we come into the Apache
Flink
dashboard we can see that the
application has been running for about 2
minutes and everything looks good
here now the sample code that was sent
is around 10,000
records and we can validate that it is
sucess Successful by coming over to our
Amazon S3 bucket which is linked in the
application main
page so we can see some of our assets
but we can also take a look at the data
that was
written click on one of these
files and query with S3 select just to
quickly see the
data and we can see that the data was
successfully written this is just sample
stock ticker
data now if you are interested in
working with the studio version of
manage service for Apache Flink let's
navigate to a different region this
blueprint in particular will only work
where msk the managed streaming for
Apache Kafka service serverless version
is available
so uh we'll click on create Studio
notebook and in the same way that we did
this before we can click use a
blueprint and again this will generate
data and write it to an Amazon msk topic
that data will then be read in to our
manage service for Apache Flink where we
can then interact with that data in an
Apache Zeppelin
notebook let's go ahead and deploy this
blueprint and we'll be back when it's
ready all right so it's been a few
minutes and now we're ready to look at
our blueprint that was created for
studio
notebooks to get started interacting
with our data in the studio notebooks
all we have to do is click on open an
Apache
Zeppelin from here we'll find the note
that was created on our behalf during
the blueprint
process
and we'll see some predefined notes in
paragraphs in the Apache Zeppelin
notebook this first paragraph is really
about defining some sample data that
we're
generating and then we can see the data
is already being queried actively from a
source table that was predefined on your
behalf this notebook is preconfigured to
listen to and consume from an msk
serverless topic
and you can see we're actively querying
this data and we can see some stock
ticker information coming
through if we did want to interact with
this data with some other sample queries
that are provided to you all you would
need to do is stop that paragraph come
down here generate some more data and
then create new paragraphs with new
queries to fit your use case and there
you have it those are the two blueprints
that are available now to use and we
will be launching additional blueprints
in the future to fit our customer
needs if you are interested in learning
more about
blueprints I will include a link to the
blueprints GitHub page that is used to
build all of the cloud formation
templates and all of the scripts used in
the blueprints Management
console this GitHub page will have links
to how to get started with blueprints
how to install them locally on your
machine and most importantly how to
modify them to fit your needs for your
specific Apache flank use case so those
are the blueprints and we're really
looking forward to seeing how our
customers are able to get started even
faster on manage service for Apache
Flink with our blueprints feature let me
know what you think in the comments I'm
Jeremy Burr and thanks for
watching
[Music]
oh
